guide.title: Gentoo Documentation Project Roadmap
guide.abstract: A TODO list for the Gentoo Documentation Project

body.p: The first and foremost task of the GDP is to fix bugs in documentation and make sure that the online documentation is available and at all times current (including translations). However, there are other tasks in which the GDP is involved. Most tasks are of temporary nature - you will find information on the progress made on these tasks in the status updates. Unfinished tasks will be mentioned next.

The main objective of the GDP is to have the online documentation be in perfect shape. Lots of users want to have offsite documentation too and even today most of them are left in the cold. The GDP should work on printable documentation (preferrably PDF), but albeit creating PDFs of its documentation isn't difficult, the main issues are:

ul.li: The online available PDFs should be fully in sync with the online HTML documentation. This requirement translates into the fact that the webserver(s) should be able to generate the PDFs on-the-fly from the sources provided.

The online available PDFs should be professionally-looking. This doesn't rhyme well with on-the-fly creation and more importantly, we currently don't have the resources to create professionally-looking PDFs.

body.p: Tim Yamin has written up a XSL-FO stylesheet to transform the Gentoo Handbook into PDF format. Example runs can be found online at his dev-page.

One of the most important goals of the GDP is to develop high-quality documentation. The following is a listing of updates and rewrites we need to do in order to keep up with the high-pace development. If a developer's name is listed, it means that (s)he has taken the challenge :)

ul.li: Update on the various /etc/portage possibilities (Mike Frysinger)

body.p: Xavier Neys proposed to add documentation-related news to the website (either the documentation index or the GDP website) on which we add items such as when documents are heavily updated (not just fixups), new documentation written, new projects started, decisions made, etc.
